species_list: Acer rubra, Quercus rubra, Pinus strobus, Tsuga canadensis
study_scale: 1 long-term ecological research location with long-term ground observations, flux towers, warming experiments
growth_metric: DBH increment, Aboveground biomass increment (gCm-2y-1), Net primary production (gCm-2y-1)
gsl_metric: the period between the first and last day of the year when NEP exceeded 30% of the mean maximum daily NEP
gsl_start_metric: first day of the year when NEP exceeded 30% of the mean maximum daily NEP
gsl_end_metric: last day of the year when NEP exceeded 30% of the mean maximum daily NEP

species_list: Aesculus hippocastanum, Betula pendula, Fagus sylvatica, Quercus robur
study_scale: experiments, long-term ground observations, and satellite-based vegetation monitoring
study_level: across years (within individuals for experiment and ground observations, within pixels for satellite based monitoring)
growth_metric: photosynthesis (MODIS gross-primary productivity, LPJ model Anetday, P model Anetday)
gsl_end_metric: EOS (dates when greenness dropped by 10% (EOS10) or 50% (EOS50) relative to the seasonal maximum)
authorsthink_evidence_gslxgrowth_notsure: sometimes growth ncreases with GSL- depends on early season vegetative activity and temperature pre- and post-solstice
ifyouthink_no_why: it does not provide evidence GSL will lead to increase growth- more complex than that as it depends on early season activitiy and temperature and
big_problems: hard to interpret the modeled Photosynthesis products
missing_something_major: focus is on EOS- they do not look at GSL explicitly, though they do use leafout so could calculate GSL?

species_list: Abies alba, Acer pseudoplatanus, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Ilex aquifolium, Quercus petraea
study_scale: 3-9 provenances (from elevations of 130-1630 m asl) per species
study_type: common garden experiment with tree seedlings
authorsfoundevidencefor_endogenousfactor: they did not do statistical tests in Table 3 at provenance level
big_problems: seedlings only and only 2 years; found strong statistical  evidence for 2/5 species in Table 3
